LGTM modulo @miguno 's comments.
LGTM modulo @miguno 's comments.

@miguno You current understanding of the change is no completely correct.

> The default timestamp extractor and the new timestamp extractor differ only in whether or not they are logging a WARN message when a message has an invalid timestamp.

The default TS extractor raises an exception, thus, killing the running instance, while the new TS extractor just logs a WARN message.

I furthermore do understand your argument about splitting extractor and handler. However, from a user point of view, assume a user wants to react on corrupted records and also does provides a custom TS extractor (ie, not using default extractor). First, user must understand that if no valid TS can be extracted, `-1` must be returned, and this will later on trigger a call to an additional error handler she must also provide. In this handler, the handling of the corrupted record will happen. So why not just handle the corrupted record directly in the extractor... that would be way more straight forward.

About local knowledge etc. If Streams policy is to silently drop records with invalid/negative timestamps, the extractor will know whats gonna happening. I don't see a big gab here.
LGTM and merged to trunk.
LGTM and merged to trunk.

Ok, LGTM. We chatted offline and this is a good temporary solution. The extra logging at a higher level shouldn't be a serious concern since it only happens during new task creation/rebalancing. We'd like to get https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3816 done so we get the context for free, but surrounding log context should be sufficient to identify the source of the config for now.
Merged to trunk and 0.10.1.
I think we should also include a test to verify that we are now throwing a `StreamsException` (rather than a `ClassCastException`).  I guess before we didn't have any test whatsoever though.

Question: The three embedded-timestamp extractors are basically all the same with the exception of the `if (timestamp < 0)` conditional logic.  Should we actually make them have e.g. a common parent class so that users see a proper a type-relationship between them? Or have the default extractor be the base class, and the two new ones override the conditional logic?
Thanks @guozhangwang. Updated based on your comments

@guozhangwang - my take on this is that you definitely should be able to do `streams.close` from an exception handler and from the Shutdown hook. The close also needs to have a timeout as people will have different requirements on how long they are willing to wait. Obviously forever is bad, but 1 minute might be deemed bad in certain cases. Also, of course, you need to be able to terminate the app from the exception handler - i guess that could be done as you suggest, but it would probably be nicer from an API/user point of view to not have to poll on the state of the `KafkaStreams` instance. Maybe we add an `awaitShutdown` method to the `KafkaStreams` (you might have been suggesting this)

Just pushed an update to this as I realised that during an execution of the exception handler, if `streams.close` was called it would never be shutdown cleanly. So to get around this i've added `StreamThread.isRunning()` and in `StreamThread.shutdown()` (which is called before the exception handler) i do `running.set(false)`. In `KafkaStreams.close(...)` only `join()` if  `!StreamThread.isRunning()`
@jjkoshy Updated PR to be robust against IO exceptions. Not doing startup time deletion yet. Ping @MayureshGharat

@jjkoshy The `failed` counter works fine when `logsToBeDeleted` grows while in the `deleteLogs` loop. It simply postpones retries to the next "round". The real questions is whether it makes sense to retry after an IO exception. It may not. If we anticipate transient IO failures on a particular disk in JBOD arrangement, this logic is perhaps simplest way to avoid head-of-the-line blocking.
This is just a quick fix

@mimaison I changed the title when merging. Hopefully it's reasonable.

One meta-comment: as for the name of `currentStreamTime`, it is not actually the `stream time` of the task we talked about before, but rather the `partition time`, and `stream time` is the min over all task's owned partition's time. Currently we are not exposing this `partition time` anywhere to the users, by doing this we are effectively doing this, and hence users need to think about `partition / stream time` in addition to `record timestamp`.
Thanks for noticing the successful run (I just wanted to mention today) and for the review!

There are some cleanups in here but I'm not sure we are adding any thread-safety (at least so long as one considers concurrent `Converter` access to be thread-safe).

As far as I can tell some thought was already put into synchronization in `KafkaConfigBackingStore` and `KafkaStatusBackingStore`.

@ewencp  
in terms of performance, 
while the Concurrenthashmap contains the AtomicInteger, the write only happens for first few concurrent calls, further calls are only increasing the AtomicInteger itself, there is no write to the ConcurrentHashMap later. 

we could do some perf test on this, so far my understanding is the impact is very very tiny.

@luafran Normally publicly-facing config changes like this would go through a KIP. The main reason I bring it up here is that while I'm sure the Java security MessageDigest options are definitely a good choice, I'm wondering if we should restrict to those simply because they are the provided options. In particular, normally with pluggable config options we make them pluggable via an interface specific to Kafka. Here we're tying things to a specific class and its set of hash algorithms, which may not be a good long term path.

LGTM.

Most changes are related to member field initialization. Before this commit, there are no guarantees that the initialization of these variables will be visible to other threads (they are not volatile, they are not final, they are not wrapped around locks, and there's no memory fence that for sure will separate their initialization from any of their reads).

By making them final and moving their initialization to the constructor we fulfill thread safety to this respect. The only one that is left out is `updateListener` but its initialization is guaranteed by the memory fence posed by `started` as long as we use it after checking `started` (which we are and makes sense to keep doing so).

Regarding synchronization around Converter, I agree that jackson and `java.lang.StringCoding` which are used under the covers for the current `Converter` implementations are thread safe. But `Converter` interface does not require (via its documentation) for its implementations to be thread-safe. Thus, we need to change either the docs or apply the changes described here (whatever we prefer)

As a side note, interestingly enough BinaryEncode instances in avro are not thread-safe. There isn't an issue because in `AvroConverter`, from what I can see briefly, because we don't reuse them (we instantiate a new one instead), but that's a difference I see from `jackson`'s object mappers. Thus we might want to be extra cautious about how the `Converter` interface is used. 

Let me know what you prefer between documentation change in Converter interface or the above changes.

Re: the field modifier changes, cool, that makes sense.

WRT `Converter`s I think we should document that we expect them to be thread-safe. cc @ewencp may have thoughts on that.

Thanks @kkonstantine, the change itself looks good to me. We should update the `Readme.md` as it references `SCALA_BINARY_VERSION` and the equivalent `bat` file for consistency as well (assuming there's an equivalent Windows command).

@ewencp Do you refer to the fact that allowed values for the new config are the values directly allowed by the underlying implementation (java.security.MessageDigest)? The concern is that if we want to change how to generate a hash, then config values may become invalid? Are you thinking about, for example, allowing users to configure the class or mechanism used to generate the digest instead of simply the hash algorithm?
In addition to the simple KIP, it would be good to include tests for the new hash algorithms.
@guozhangwang @gwenshap  plz review
May be worth noting that hash algorithms can be added to `MessageDigest`using standard Java security providers. So it might not be necessary to add a Kafka-specific interface for extensibility.

Should tests be updated?

Had a closer look at the javadoc for `available`: ``` java * Returns an estimate of the number of bytes that can be read (or * skipped over) from this input stream without blocking by the next * invocation of a method for this input stream. The next invocation * might be the same thread or another thread. A single read or skip of this * many bytes will not block, but may read or skip fewer bytes. * *

Note that while some implementations of {@code InputStream} will return * the total number of bytes in the stream, many will not. It is * never correct to use the return value of this method to allocate * a buffer intended to hold all data in this stream. * *

A subclass' implementation of this method may choose to throw an * {@link IOException} if this input stream has been closed by * invoking the {@link #close()} method. * *

The {@code available} method for class {@code InputStream} always * returns {@code 0}. * *

This method should be overridden by subclasses. * * @return an estimate of the number of bytes that can be read (or skipped * over) from this input stream without blocking or {@code 0} when * it reaches the end of the input stream. * @exception IOException if an I/O error occurs. ``` So even though I think it makes sense to avoid the exceptions, it seems a bit brittle to rely on that method as an alternative to reading until the end. Yes, we are overriding all the implementations to tighten the contract, but it seems possible that someone would add a new implementation that satisfies the contract and breaks the current expectation. It would seem that it would be better to have a separate method (and an interface perhaps) that does what we need?
`upgrade.html` is in `docs` folder. Not sure what you mean by "a update not for this PR".

Yes we did notice that detail and it's a valid concern. Your suggestion on having a more explicit interface makes sense. The codecs extend a sealed trait and we could add some protection (in the tests) that all codecs are tested.
